Literature Review: The concept of refeudalization has emerged as a critical lens through which contemporary socio-political and legal transformations are being analyzed. This literature review delves into the multifaceted dimensions of refeudalization, particularly its implications for the rule of law, sovereignty, democracy, representation, and contractualization. Drawing on a diverse body of scholarly work, this review aims to elucidate the complex interplay between historical feudal structures and modern legal and political systems. The privatization of public authority and responsibilities stands as a cornerstone in the discourse on refeudalization. Scholars argue that the erosion of the public sphere and the increasing delegation of state functions to private entities mirror the feudal practice of granting fiefdoms to vassals in exchange for loyalty and service. This shift not only challenges the traditional boundaries between public and private law but also raises questions about accountability and the democratic legitimacy of such arrangements. The territorial unbundling of sovereignty further complicates the legal landscape, as multiple, overlapping authorities and jurisdictions emerge, reminiscent of the fragmented sovereignty characteristic of feudal societies. This phenomenon undermines the Westphalian model of state sovereignty and necessitates a reevaluation of legal frameworks to accommodate the complexities of global governance. Contractualization, both of individuals and political units, represents another dimension of refeudalization. The transformation of social and political relationships into contractual agreements echoes the feudal bonds of allegiance, where personal loyalty and mutual obligations defined the social order. This contractualization process has significant implications for the concept of citizenship and the nature of political representation, as it shifts the basis of political legitimacy from collective democratic processes to individual contractual arrangements. The changing relationship between sovereignty and political representation in the context of refeudalization also warrants attention. As traditional forms of political representation are increasingly bypassed in favor of direct relationships between rulers and ruled, the democratic foundations of modern political systems are called into question. This trend towards personalized governance, akin to the feudal lord-vassal relationship, challenges the principles of equality and universality that underpin the rule of law. In conclusion, the concept of refeudalization offers a valuable framework for understanding the ongoing transformations in law, society, and politics. By drawing parallels between historical feudal structures and contemporary developments, scholars can gain insights into the challenges facing the rule of law, sovereignty, democracy, and representation in the modern era. As the boundaries between public and private, national and global, and individual and collective continue to blur, the need for a nuanced understanding of these processes becomes ever more pressing.
